com.metsci.glimpse.gl

Class GLStreamingBuffer

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.metsci.glimpse.gl.GLStreamingBuffer

  • public class GLStreamingBuffer
extends Object
    Represents a device buffer that needs to be re-written frequently, and frequently read for rendering as well. Helpful for migrating away from immediate-mode rendering.

    Uses the recommended approach for buffer object streaming. Specifically:

    1. Allocate a large block of device-buffer memory
    2. Write to a small section of the block
    3. Render using the written section
    4. Write to the next section of the block
    5. Render using the newly written section
    6. Repeat
    7. Once the whole block has been used, allocate a new block
    When a new block is allocated, the old block is dereferenced, but not actually deleted until pending render operations are done with it. This approach avoids driver-level synchronization, because the new block can be written to without waiting for pending render operations to finish.

    The cost is an increase in device-memory allocations. However, allocating in large blocks keeps the frequency of allocations down. Furthermore, in most cases, successive blocks will be the same size, so it is reasonable to assume that old blocks will be recycled by the driver's memory manager. For more info see the explanation here.

    Expected usage looks something like this: 

        // At init-time

    GLStreamingBuffer xyVbo = new GLStreamingBuffer( GL_ARRAY_BUFFER, GL_STREAM_DRAW, 100 );
    ...

    // At render-time

    int maxVertices = 10000;
    int floatsPerVertex = 2;
    FloatBuffer xyBuffer = xyVbo.mapFloats( gl, floatsPerVertex * maxVertices );

    xyBuffer.put( x0 ).put( y0 );
    xyBuffer.put( x1 ).put( y1 );
    ...

    int numVertices = xyBuffer.position( ) / floatsPerVertex;
    xyVbo.seal( gl );

    gl.glBindBuffer( xyVbo.target, xyVbo.buffer( ) );
    gl.glVertexAttribPointer( ..., xyVbo.sealedOffset( ) );
    gl.glDrawArrays( ..., 0, numVertices );

    • Method Detail

      • buffer

        public int buffer(javax.media.opengl.GL gl)
        Returns the buffer handle, as created by e.g. GL.glGenBuffers(int, java.nio.IntBuffer).

      • sealedOffset

        public long sealedOffset()
        Returns the offset into #buffer() of the most recently sealed range -- e.g. for use with GL2ES2.glVertexAttribPointer(int, int, int, boolean, int, long).

        Returns -1 if seal(GL) has not been called yet.

      • setFloats

        public void setFloats(javax.media.opengl.GL gl,
                      FloatBuffer floats)
        Convenience method that maps a region, copies data into it using FloatBuffer.put(FloatBuffer), and then seals the region.

        Note that this will modify the buffer's position.

      • setDoubles

        public void setDoubles(javax.media.opengl.GL gl,
                       DoubleBuffer doubles)
        Convenience method that maps a region, copies data into it using DoubleBuffer.put(DoubleBuffer), and then seals the region.

        Note that this will modify the buffer's position.

      • setInts

        public void setInts(javax.media.opengl.GL gl,
                    IntBuffer ints)
        Convenience method that maps a region, copies data into it using IntBuffer.put(IntBuffer), and then seals the region.

        Note that this will modify the buffer's position.

      • setBytes

        public void setBytes(javax.media.opengl.GL gl,
                     ByteBuffer bytes)
        Convenience method that maps a region, copies data into it using ByteBuffer.put(ByteBuffer), and then seals the region.

        Note that this will modify the buffer's position.

      • mapFloats

        public FloatBuffer mapFloats(javax.media.opengl.GL gl,
                             long numFloats)
        Convenience wrapper around mapBytes(GL, long) -- converts numFloats to a byte count, and converts the returned buffer to a FloatBuffer.

                               long numDoubles)
        Convenience wrapper around mapBytes(GL, long) -- converts numDoubles to a byte count, and converts the returned buffer to a DoubleBuffer.

      • mapInts

        public IntBuffer mapInts(javax.media.opengl.GL gl,
                         long numInts)
        Convenience wrapper around mapBytes(GL, long) -- converts numInts to a byte count, and converts the returned buffer to an IntBuffer.

      • mapBytes

        public ByteBuffer mapBytes(javax.media.opengl.GL gl,
                           long numBytes)
        Returns a buffer representing host memory owned by the graphics driver. The returned buffer should be treated as write-only. After writing to the buffer, call seal(GL) to indicate to the driver that the newly written contents are ready to be pushed to the device.

        It is okay to request more bytes than will actually be written, as long as you then avoid actually trying to use the values in the unwritten region (e.g. by passing the appropriate number of vertices to GL.glDrawArrays(int, int, int).

        Note, however, that the driver may push the entire mapped region to the device -- so while numBytes is an upper bound, it should be a reasonably tight upper bound.

      • seal

        public void seal(javax.media.opengl.GL gl)
        Unmaps the currently mapped range. After this, the sealed range can be read by GL calls.

      • dispose

        public void dispose(javax.media.opengl.GL gl)
        Deletes the buffer (unmapping first, if necessary), and resets this object to the way it was before mapBytes(GL, long) was first called.

        This object can be safely reused after being disposed, but in most cases there is no significant advantage to doing so.
